channel.title: Choosing what programming language?
channel.description:
So, I have been thinking for the past few days now and doing some research on most of the computer programming languages, but I cant seem to be able to pick one and start to master it.
I am asking for your opinion what computer language should i learn first? I have some experience with Java and VB but I can never stick to them.
If you could please comment your opinion on what programming language I should learn first that would be great!

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Sup22211 Sup22211
item.description:
@Sup22211 wrote:

Java.

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?

Thanks for all the suggestions!!

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @S_v2 .S. v2
item.description:
@S_v2 wrote:

Don’t start with Java. I started with Java. It was a terrible decision.

Start with a functional language or C.

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Hash1, post:32, topic:490673”]If you want to do Android applications, do Java and Objective-C for iOS.[/quote]I’d recommend Javascript and you’re developing for both without the need for porting :).

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?

item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

If you want to do Android applications, do Java and Objective-C for iOS.

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

Fire capez:

are people really recommending functional languages to start with?

A lot of universities actually teach functional programming first.

robonick8:

AHHH :eek: since you seem like an educated person, do you think i should learn c++ or learn python since people are saying it will make it easier

C++ is one of those languages that you really need to learn thoroughly if you’re serious. It’s not simple, and there are a lot of pitfalls. Personally, I recommend picking up a good book (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/388242/the-definitive-c-book-guide-and-list), but there might online tutorials that are decent. After that, pick up another book that teaches you good practices, e.g. Effective C++. It’s almost imperative that you do this, because of the pitfalls I mentioned.

Python on the other hand is much simpler, and compared to C++, you’ve pretty much got your hand held the whole time. For a beginner, I recommend it over C++. I suppose if you want a language closer to C++, there’s always Java or C#.

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

are people really recommending functional languages to start with? python would be a good idea, c/c++ is only really needed in situations where really good performance is required.

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @ox_random_xi ox random xi
item.description:
@ox_random_xi wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:28, topic:490673”][quote author=robonick8 link=topic=608906.msg4233250#msg4233250 date=1361411343]

I am considering C++ to start with

Good luck… you’ll need it

AHHH :eek: since you seem like an educated person, do you think i should learn c++ or learn python since people are saying it will make it easier
[/quote]
I’d start with Python just primarily because it’ll get you in the habit of producing neat and tidy code :P. Not to mention its easy to learn syntax etc, then you can move on to bigger and better languages :P[/quote]
Aha, someone agrees with me!

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @ox_random_xi ox random xi
item.description:
@ox_random_xi wrote:

robonick8:

Well what I want to do with programming is develop IOS and Andrioid applications and possibly operating systems ran in phones and I know thats all Objective C. But, I would also like to develop games such and such and I know Java is the way to go for that. I have been reading through all comments and people have been saying Python, C/C++ would be the best to stat with because it would make all the other languages a lot easier to learn. I appreciate everyone’s tips, and I am considering C++ to start with

python makes C++ easier to learn

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“ox random xi, post:19, topic:490673”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=608906.msg4232804#msg4232804 date=1361390130]

I’m mobile so I can’t really go through the other replies but I recommend starting with python, that’s what they’re teaching beginner programming classes now instead of C#

Python is a good language to have under your belt, also with incorrect indentation throwing errors it’s good for formatting beginners code and it’ll get them in the habit of it :P.
[/quote]
That’s what I’m going to try learning on my own right now before I start off with anything else and before I go into college.[/quote]
Good luck

Read full topic

item.title: Choosing what programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Arcik, post:15, topic:490673”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=608906.msg4232758#msg4232758 date=1361387068]

html

That is not a programming language, its a markup language, hence why its called Hypertext Markup Language.

I personally prefer Java as I know it the best out of Java, C#, and VB.net that I know. It just all depends on what you plan to do as said above. C/C++, also as said above, will give you many headaches and be a major pain in the ass to start with.
[/quote]

php[/quote]
Wouldn’t really recommend anyone into learning PHP unless they were specifically looking at website development, and even then I’d get them to learn a language before hand. PHP is an absolutely terrible language :P. If I could have learnt Ruby before learning anything else programming wise I think I’d be an all-round better programmer as opposed to learning PHP first. Just speaking from experience :o

Read full topic
